head.supplied: Port Moresby ¶ New Guinea ¶ May 7, 1886 ¶ A. C. McDonald Esqr FRGS. ¶ Dear Mr Macdonald,...

div.p: A36, Royal Geographical Society of Australasia (Vic. Branch) papers, Mitchell Library, State Library of New South Wales, Sydney.
I have just recd your kind note covering copy of Resolutions from the Victorian to New South Wales branch of Geogl Scty re Mr Forbes.
Please give my sincere thanks to the Council for the honour conferred upon me in making me an Honorary member of your Society.
I was a little surprised at the tone of the Resolutions but I am sure they arose from a misunderstanding of Mr Forbes position and work.
I have written fully to the President of the New South Wales branch and Mr Forbes has written to your honoured President.

Mr Forbes is now sending his herbarium an exact duplicate of that which he has taken with him for the British Museum. This is the earliest date at which he could do this. Heavy rains and prevailing sickness has practically cut off all communication with the interior for some months past. It was with great difficulties that he got 150 native carriers to bring down his stuff to the coast.
His report has yet to be prepared. He has been single handed so far as European help is concerned since January last.
Not a single specimen has been sent away nor line of Report written. It has been impossible to do so, and so far as I see Mr Forbes is adhering to the letter of his agreement.

He has written fully to Sir E Strickland and also to Baron von Mueller. I am sure he has not received any letter which has been unanswered. You must not forget that our mail opportunities are very few. Only three opportunities have occurred for sending letters since 18th December —

I think when you have all the facts before you, you will see that Mr Forbes has not been neglectful of your interests and will accord him sympathy for being obliged to abandon his expedition when it was within appreciable distance of success —
